image.altText: A large, dark and ominous cloud hangs over the Darwin skyline

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology issues a severe weather warning for residents across the coastal Top End and Tiwi Islands, urging them to brace for potentially damaging winds and rainfall totals of up to 160mm in just six hours.

title.children: Top End residents on alert for 90kph winds and flash flooding as tropical monsoon ramps up

image.altText: Nicole Manison laughs during a press conference with Natasha Fyles in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The former deputy chief minister's decision not to contest the next election means three of the most prominent figures from the past two elections are on the backbench or out of politics.

title.children: Nicole Manison's resignation marks the end of an era for Territory Labor, and an opportunity for the CLP

image.altText: A sign on a fence in front of a snow-covered house says 'Trump Make America Great Again'

props.synopsis: This week's Iowa caucuses signal the start of the primary race for the 2024 US election. Donald Trump's the strongest polling Republican, but many caucus-goers say there are better options.

title.children: 'So many Trump haters': As a small state holds first big US vote, some Republicans are turning

image.altText: A slightly smiling Indigenous man stands in front of red rocks, looks down on camera, green trees, black t-shirt, black cap.

props.synopsis: In Alice Springs, addiction has a stranglehold. But a group of local Aboriginal men are hoping to break cycles, one conversation at a time.

title.children: Little-used addiction recovery program quadruples in popularity after on-country healing

image.altText: A group of people waving flags

props.synopsis: Beijing despises the winner of Taiwan's election, Lai Ching-tei, calling him a separatist and a troublemaker. But it can't ignore the message voters are sending with his victory, writes Kathleen Calderwood.

title.children: Taiwan just had an election. The outcome sends a big message to China

image.altText: Adam Walton

props.synopsis: The Australian Open has arrived with four Aussies in action and Novak Djokovic kicking off the night session on day one at Melbourne Park. Follow live.

title.children: Aussie wildcard drops first two sets on day one of the Australian Open

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie Adam Walton is two sets down in his first-round clash
We have our first winner of the tournament
Australian Adam Walton drops the first set in a tie-break

image.altText: A woman with dyed red hair and glasses in a tie and suit vest and a woman with blonde hair and a green sweater

props.synopsis: The Pope's recent pronouncement against surrogacy has sparked heated global debate about the controversial issue. In Australia, surrogacy is complex: deplored by some but embraced by others whose lives have been transformed by remarkable acts of generosity and love.

title.children: Alice and Olivia were both conceived via surrogacy. Today, they have contrasting views on the controversial practice

image.altText: Left to right: Ben Shelton, Jannik Sinner, Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Sebastian Korda.

props.synopsis: Father time comes for everyone. Except it seems for Novak Djokovic but even the Serbian great can't stave off generation after generation forever and now could be their time to do the seemingly impossible.

title.children: Novak Djokovic is tennis's alpha male but he is being hunted by a generation who don't fear him

image.altText: Sam Kerr

props.synopsis: Matildas star Samantha Kerr posts a photo from hospital asking for Netflix recommendations, after going under the knife to fix her torn ACL.

title.children: Sam Kerr posts upbeat photo from hospital after undergoing surgery to fix her ACL

image.altText: A couple in evening wear

props.synopsis: When Crown Prince Frederik and his Australian-born wife Princess Mary ascend the throne overnight, it will be a simple, pared-back affair. But it's all part of a centuries-long effort to keep the Danish monarchy going.

title.children: The key to the Danish monarchy's survival is 'informality'. Here's how Mary became their secret weapon

image.altText: Dad whale on a beach.

props.synopsis: The death of a suspected fin whale has provided the Australian Museum with what could be only the third set of tissue samples gathered from the species in almost 200 years.

title.children: Beached whale provides 'really rare opportunity' for research into elusive fin species

image.altText: A Palestinian woman walks near the rubble of a house destroyed in an Israeli strike.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Palestinian Australians are waiting for family members with approved visas to get a green light from border officials to leave Gaza.

title.children: Palestinian Australians say their families can't leave Gaza despite having a valid Australian visa

image.altText: a young african man sitting behind weights at a gym

props.synopsis: Yiel Gatluak, 19, was found dead on a remote road near Alice Springs on New Year's Day. NT detectives are expected to apply to a Victorian court for the extradition of a fourth person arrested in relation to his death.

title.children: Fourth person arrested in Victoria over suspicious death of teen near Alice Springs

image.altText: People on the sand and water with life savers under an umbrella on Mackenzies Bay beach

props.synopsis: The mysterious appearance and disappearance of sand at a bay in Sydney's east has caused both intrigue and headaches for decades, depending on who you are.

title.children: 'Not for the faint-hearted': People told to stay away from mysterious Sydney beach

image.altText: Boeing ANA

props.synopsis: A domestic flight of Japan's All Nippon Airways returns to its departure airport after a crack was found on the cockpit window of the Boeing 737-800 aircraft.

title.children: Boeing aircraft turns back after crack found in cockpit window

image.altText: An alive elderly woman smiles as she lies in her handmade wooden coffin

props.synopsis: Books, boxes and knick-knacks might be stored in your spare room, but in Mary Flynn's home studio is a wooden coffin, which she made herself. She's never been frightened of death and wants to spark conversations about natural burials.

title.children: Mary has made her own biodegradable coffin — and knows exactly where she would like to be buried

image.altText: A family of four standing outside their electric 4WD and camper

props.synopsis: "Green power couple" Tim and Renae McLennan want to be one of the first to travel around Australia using an electric vehicle to tow a pop-up caravan.

title.children: How this Perth family plans to make the great Australian road trip better for the planet

image.altText: A woman smiling wearing a white dress holding onto a man wearing a black blazer and a white shirt.

props.synopsis: Jacinda Ardern had to reschedule her wedding in 2022 because of lockdown restrictions.

title.children: Former NZ prime minister ties the knot after engagement of nearly five years

image.altText: A young girl serving a tennis ball

props.synopsis: In just a few years, blind and low-vision tennis has become Australia's fastest-growing blind sport, with Australians now dominating the world stage.

title.children: 'More than just a game': Why Kala joined Australia's fastest growing blind sport

image.altText: water over double-lane highway

props.synopsis: Authorities remind the public constantly that floodwaters and cars don't mix, but drivers continue to take the risk. Here's what experts say about why people do it.

title.children: After more than 50 swift-water rescues in Victoria this week, why do people keep driving into floods?

image.altText: Rescuers at a landslide location in Columbia.

props.synopsis: A mudslide brought on by heavy rains hits a busy highway in north-west Colombia, killing dozens of people and injuring dozens more on.

title.children: Landslide in north-west Colombia kills dozens of people

image.altText: Maldivian resort

props.synopsis: The Maldives stands to lose hundreds of millions of dollars as its giant neighbour threatens to halt its tourism there. But why is the world's most populous country flexing its muscles in that way, and what's China got to do with it?

title.children: India hits a tiny island nation where it hurts: tourism. But why?

image.altText: A snake dangles from an ice dispenser on a fridge door.

props.synopsis: When she went to turn off the radio in her outdoor entertainment area, Adelaide Hills resident Gail Auricht thought the hissing sound she could hear was an air compressor — then she spotted a red-bellied black snake caught in her fridge.

title.children: 'Enough to send a chill down anyone's spine': Snake found dangling down from ice dispenser on fridge door

image.altText: Thelma Krause

props.synopsis: Ex-Chicago Bulls stars express their disgust after Thelma Krause was moved to tears as Bulls fans booed her late husband during a ceremony meant to honour the former general manager.

title.children: 'It's absolutely shameful': Former Bulls stars hit out after booing fans move widow to tears during ceremony

image.altText: Firefighters with hoses near a line of smouldering trees.

props.synopsis: Two bushfire emergency warnings in the Shire of Chittering, north of Perth, are downgraded, but authorities warn the blazes are not contained or controlled.

title.children: Bushfires that threatened lives, homes in Shire of Chittering downgraded, but remain uncontained and uncontrolled

image.altText: Patients being treated at the Royal Melbourne Hospital road trauma unit.

props.synopsis: Last year was the deadliest on Australia's roads in five years, but there's no national record of how many people were left injured.

title.children: Kate works at one of Australia's busiest hospitals. Road injuries represent a 'huge chunk' of its cases

image.altText: a killer whale in the water

props.synopsis: Pods of more than 70 orcas have been recorded at the Bremer Canyon off Western Australia's south coast as the annual season starts with high numbers of killer whales in good health.

title.children: Bremer Bay orcas 'healthiest on the globe' as numbers boom off Western Australia
